Topchiev Institute of Petrochemical Synthesis, Russian Academy of Sciences, Leninsky prospect, 29, Moscow, 119991 Russia ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 ORCID: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-2908-0353. 2 ORCID: https://orcid.org/0000-0003-0307-8017. 3 ORCID: https://orcid.org/0000-0001-9054-0905. 4 ORCID: http://orcid.org/0000-0001-9297-4950. The catalytic activity of unsupported NiMoS catalysts prepared in situ by thermal decomposition of the [(CH3)3S]2Ni(MoS4)2 precursor was studied in the course of diphenyl ether hydrodeoxygenation. The resulting catalysts were characterized using the transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). It was demonstrated that the diphenyl ether conversion naturally decreases with a decrease in the precursor loading. The effect of changes in the amount of the added sulfiding agent on the morphological and structural features of the formed catalysts was studied. It was found that reducing the amount of elemental sulfur from 2.5 to 0.5 wt% results in a more active sulfide NiMo catalyst, which is explained by an increase in the dispersion of the active phase particles from 0.24 to 0.34. A route of diphenyl ether hydrodeoxygenation on unsupported NiMoS catalysts was studied and suggested by varying the reaction time and hydrogen pressure in the system. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Nickel-molybdenum sulfide catalysts Dispersed catalysts In situ Lignin Diphenyl ether Hydrodeoxygenation Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction The gradual depletion of fossil fuel reserves along with the widely available lignocellulosic biomass is the reason for the growing interest in studying its processing options. Cellulose conversion, primarily into glucose, bioethanol, vanillin, etc., was commercialized and introduced into industry long ago [1,2]. But the development of efficient lignin processing techniques is still a topical issue to be addressed. Due to its structure, lignin is the largest renewable source of aromatic hydrocarbons on the planet, obtained from a completely renewable natural feedstock [3,4]. With that a wide variety of both carbon-carbon and ether bonds in the lignin structure determines its resistance to various degradation methods [5]. Nevertheless, lignin has a huge chemical and technological potential from the viewpoint of obtaining valuable chemical compounds with an added value. Modern approaches to lignin processing are aimed at breaking the C-C/C-O bonds to produce monomeric and dimeric oxygen-containing compounds [6] that represent intermediate products for the production of carbon-containing fuels and various chemical compounds [7,8]. The resulting oxygen-containing compounds [9] with various functional groups undergo further catalytic processing with a view to obtaining certain products (phenol, arenes, cycloalkanes, etc.) [10,11]. However, lignin processing is complicated by its structure that has several types of ether bonds, namely β-O-4, α-O-4 and 4-O-5 [8,12], of which the β-O-4 bond is predominant [13]. The least reactive bond is 4-O-5, which is due to the absence of the Caliphatic-O bonds known to have a lower breaking energy than Caromatic-O [14]. From this point of view, the 4-O-5 bond is the most stable ether bond in the lignin structure. Therefore, studying the possibilities of 4-O-5 bond cleavage is important both for lignin depolymerization into small molecules and for hydrocarbon production. One of the processes solving the problem is hydrodeoxygenation (HDO), a popular and widely used method of removing oxygen from phenolic compounds, which includes hydrogenation and deoxygenation [8,15]. The hydrodeoxygenation process is known to offer two ways direct deoxygenation or hydrogenation of the aromatic ring at the initial stage followed by oxygen removal [16,17]. Ni-Mo or Co-Mo based systems are used as hydroprocessing catalysts in industry [17,18]. Supported NiMo/Al2O3 sulfide hydrotreatment catalysts have shown good results in hydrodeoxygenation processes [15,19,20]. However, the catalyst support is known to have a significant impact on the composition of hydrodeoxygenation products [21]. In particular, presence of the catalyst support leads to such side reactions as hydrocracking and isomerization, as well as to carbon deposition on the catalyst surface [22–24]. On the other hand, depending on the type of oxygen-containing functional groups, their presence in the feedstock may affect catalyst support deactivation [25]. Besides, the water contained in the feedstock and produced during hydrodeoxygenation leads to some loss in the catalyst surface area as a result of partial recrystallization of alumina support into a hydrated form represented by boehmite [26,27]. However the use of unsupported bimetallic catalysts that proved to be highly active in the petroleum fraction hydrotreating processes can be a solution to some of these problems [28]. The high dispersion degree of sulfide catalyst particles, and hence the catalyst activity, is usually achieved by introducing into the feedstock those catalyst precursors that decompose to form an active sulfide catalyst in situ [29]. In terms of their nature, precursors are divided into water and oil-soluble [30–32]. The common disadvantage of both groups of the precursors is only one metal contained in the compounds; therefore precursors of different metals need to be combined for obtaining bimetallic catalysts. This problem could be solved by using sulfonium thiosalts that contain both a promoting metal and an active metal. The type of precursor used is known to have a direct impact on the size of sulfide catalyst particles, which in its turn results in a larger surface area and increases the number of active sites in the catalyst [33]. Another way to effective control the size of obtained particles is to use various solvent systems, which has been demonstrated by the example of CoMoS catalysts [34]. Another study has shown that adding Ni as a promoter has an impact not only on the catalytic properties, but on the morphology of the resulting catalysts as well. In particular, its addition prevents the growth of Mo sulfide particles and reduces the surface area as the amount of added nickel is increased [35]. The recent studies of the stability of unsupported catalysts by the example of molybdenum sulfide revealed that less coke is formed on its surface as compared to a supported analog. It was also demonstrated that in the case of an unsupported catalyst, active phase decomposition had no significant impact on its deactivation [36]. It should be noted that there are discrepancies in the publications regarding the promoting effect of Ni (Co) metals and their influence on the route of the hydrodeoxygenation reaction. In particular, it is noted in [37,38] that Ni promotion results in the hydrodeoxygenation of aliphatic oxygen-containing compounds, rather than in the decarboxylation and decarbonylation as compared to Co promotion. For aromatic oxygen-containing compounds, Co promotion is known to result in the direct deoxygenation, and Ni promotion, in the hydrogenation [39,40]. One way to increase the catalyst activity [40] and prevent its oxidation is to maintain an active sulfide form of the catalyst system, in particular by adding a sulfiding agent (H2S) during the hydrodeoxygenation process [41]. The authors [15] suggested that H2S added to the system as a sulfiding agent is responsible for the creation and retention of nucleophilic SH-groups on the sulfide catalyst during hydrodeoxygenation of a wide range of model compounds, which in its turn activates the oxygen-containing compounds. Therefore, the ability of nucleophilic SH-groups to interact with oxygenates is one of the main factors affecting the initial general reactivity of the starter compounds. Nevertheless, there is a number of studies demonstrating a negative impact of adding a sulfiding agent to the system. In particular, it was noted in [42] that the H2S added to the system can simultaneously inhibit the reaction. However, it was demonstrated [39] that the inhibitory effect depends on the type of oxygen-containing functional groups and reaction mechanism. Oxygen and sulfur are also reported to be competing for the same active sites [43]. Despite the fact that sulfide catalysts are used in industry for hydrodesulfurization of petroleum fractions and allow reducing the sulfur content to several ppm [44], adding a sulfiding agent to the system during the hydrodeoxygenation process can nonetheless result in sulfur getting into the deoxygenated compounds and, thereby, occurring in the products obtained [39,45]. This paper demonstrates the catalytic properties of unsupported NiMoS catalysts prepared in situ by thermal decomposition of the [(CH3)3S]2Ni(MoS4)2 precursor. The activity of obtained catalysts was studied in the course of hydrodeoxygenation of diphenyl ether as a model compound of the 4-O-5 bond contained in the lignin structure. The aim of the paper is to study the way the amount of sulfur added as a sulfiding agent impacts the catalysts formation peculiarities and composition of the products obtained. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals All chemicals were used without additional treatment. A 10 wt% solution of diphenyl ether (Vekton JSC, >98%) in octane (CARLO ERBA Reagents, >99%) was used as a substrate simulating the 4-O-5 bond in the lignin structure. NiCl2·6H2O (Sigma-Aldrich, >99.99%,), CH3CN (Komponent-Reaktiv LLC, >99.8%), (NH4)2MoS4 (Sigma-Aldrich, >99.97%), (CH3)3BrS (Sigma-Aldrich, >97%), isopropyl alcohol (Komponent-Reaktiv LLC, >99.8%) and petroleum ether (Komponent-Reaktiv LLC, >95%) were used for the [(CH3)3S]2Ni(MoS4)2 precursor synthesis. Elemental sulfur (Komponent-Reaktiv LLC, >99.99%) was used as a sulfiding agent. 2.2 Catalytic reactions A series of NiMoSx catalysts was obtained in situ by thermal decomposition of the [(CH3)3S]2Ni(MoS4)2 precursor. The precursor was synthesized using our own method described earlier [44]. The amount of the added sulfiding agent was varied between 0.25, 0.5 and 2.5 wt% in terms of diphenyl ether solution in octane when preparing the catalysts. A series of NiMoS0.25, NiMoS0.5, NiMoS2.5 catalysts was obtained. Catalytic experiments for the entire series of in situ prepared NiMoS0.25, NiMoS0.5, and NiMoS2.5 catalysts were carried out in a batch autoclave-type reactor with constant stirring, in a hydrogen atmosphere under an initial pressure of 5 MPa for 5 h. The reactor was loaded with an accurate amount (2 g) of a 10 wt% solution of DPE in octane. The precursor loading is calculated relative to DPE. The activity of catalysts during hydrodeoxygenation was studied by varying the substrate:Mo molar ratio between 10.5:1, 40:1, 70.5:1 and 105.3:1 at 360 and 380 °С. The reaction mixture was heated uniformly. The control was carried out using an internal thermocouple. For a more detailed study of the supposed reaction route, a series of experiments undertaken by varying the reaction time between 2, 5, 7, and 10 h and varying the hydrogen initial pressure between 1, 3, 5 and 7 MPa at a substrate:Mo molar ratio of 40:1. 2.3 Product analysis The qualitative analysis of liquid products was conducted using the Thermo Scientific ISQ 7000 single quadrupole GC−MS equipped with a Restek 5XI-17SIL MS CAP capillary column (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 µm). The quantitative analysis of liquid products was conducted using the Crystallux 4000 M gas-liquid chromatograph (NPF MetaKhrom, LLC) with a flame ionization detector and an SPB capillary column (Superlco, 30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 µm), with helium used as a carrier gas. The conversion of diphenyl ether was calculated as the degree of conversion of the initial oxygen-containing compound into to all reaction products according to the following formula: (1) Conversion % = ∑ S p ∑ S p + S DPE × 100 % # where S p is the peak area of the reaction products and S DPE is the peak area of the unreacted diphenyl ether. The content of main reaction products was calculated according to the following formula: (2) Content % = S i ∑ S p + S DPE × 100 % # where S i is the peak area of i-product of the reaction. 2.4 Catalyst characterization The morphology of the obtained catalysts was studied from images obtained using the TEM Tecnai Osiris (FEI) electron microscope equipped with an X-FEG electron source (at an accelerating voltage of 200 keV). EDX elemental distribution maps were generated using a high angle annular dark field (HAADF) (see “Supplementary information”). The obtained images were processed through a statistical analysis using the GATAN Digital Micrograph software. Approximately 20 micrographs for each sample were processed to obtain distributions. To estimate the dispersion (D) of obtained catalysts, L ¯ (the average length of sulfide particles) and N ¯ (the average stacking number) were calculated. (3) L ¯ = ∑ l i n # where l i is the length of each sulfide particle (nm) and n is the total number of sulfide particles. (4) N ¯ = ∑ n i N i n # where N i is a number of sulfide layers in i-crystallite and n i is the number of particles with a N i layers. The dispersion formula for the active phase particles was derived from formulas given in papers [46,47]. (5) D = 12.5 * L ̅ − 4 3.125 * L ̅ 2 # The surface phase composition of the prepared catalysts was studied by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) using an upgraded ES 2403 electron spectrometer equipped with a PHOIBOS 100–5MCD (Specs GmbH) energy analyzer and MgKα/AlKα XR-50 (Specs GmbH) X-ray source. Binding energies were determined with C1s peak (284.9 eV) as the reference. A Shirley background subtraction and Gaussian−Lorentzian line shapes with 70% Gaussian/30% Lorentzian proportion was applied for peak fitting of the spectra. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic testing The ether bond cleavage in the reaction of model compounds containing the 4-O-5 bond includes breakdown of the ether bond to form phenol as the main product, which can lead, among other things, to lignin depolymerization [7]. The simplest compound simulating this type of bond is diphenyl ether (DPE). The activity of in situ formed NiMoS catalysts in the course of hydrodeoxygenation of diphenyl ether was studied with the addition of elemental sulfur in an amount of 2.5 wt%. Both at 360 °C and 380 °C, the diphenyl ether conversion decreases naturally as the precursor loading is decreased ( Fig. 1). The main product is cyclohexane irrespective of the reaction conditions. However, the share of phenol in the reaction products increases as the temperature gets lower. This may indicate a decrease in the deoxygenating activity of the obtained catalysts with a decrease in the reaction temperature. Since it is noted in the publications that adding a sulfiding agent to the system can lead to the inclusion of sulfur in the resulting products, our work was focused on studying the effect of a lower amount of elemental sulfur on the activity of the obtained catalysts. However, when running a hydrodeoxygenation process on NiMoS catalytic systems, it is important to bear in mind that their catalytic activity mainly depends on the active sulfide phase [44]. A 5-time reduction of the sulfiding agent content to 0.5 wt% not only failed to provide the expected decrease in the catalytic activity of the NiMoS catalysts, but rather led to a higher degree of substrate conversion. In particular, at 380 °С the diphenyl ether conversion remains close to 100% even at a substrate:Mo molar ratio of 70.5:1, and reaches 76% in the case of the minimum precursor loading ( Fig. 2 (2A)). This temperature also resulted in the highest cyclohexane content (80%). However, a temperature decrease down to 360 °C resulted in phenol entering the reaction products at a substrate:Mo molar ratio of 70.5:1 (Fig. 2 (1A)). A further decrease in the sulfiding agent content down to 0.25 wt% led to a significantly lower diphenyl ether conversion. In particular, at 360, and at 380 °C the diphenyl ether conversion reached < 40% at a substrate:Mo molar ratio of 105.3:1 (Fig. 2 (B)). Besides, the predominant reaction product at the same loading and at 380 °C is phenol. To study the possible route of the hydrodeoxygenation reaction on the in situ prepared NiMoS0.5 catalyst, the reaction time and hydrogen pressure in the system were varied ( Fig. 3). When studying the impact of the reaction time on the diphenyl ether hydrodeoxygenation process, it was found that the conversion reaches > 95% at 7 h. At a longer reaction time, the products composition changes towards a lower amount of phenol and a higher amount of benzene and cyclohexane, respectively (Fig. 3(A)). As it can be seen from Fig. 3(B), changing the hydrogen pressure in the system from 1 to 7 MPa leads to a higher conversion of diphenyl ether, which reaches 100% at 7 MPa. The main reaction products at 1 and 3 MPa are benzene and phenol, which indicates an incomplete hydrodeoxygenation process under these conditions and correlates with the conversion values. In case of further pressure increase, the main reaction product is cyclohexane. Its content reaches the maximum value at a H2 pressure of 7 MPa (46%). Therefore, the reaction can be shifted towards hydrogenation by increasing the pressure. The obtained data make it possible to suggest a route for diphenyl ether hydrodeoxygenation on in situ prepared NiMoS catalysts ( Fig. 4). The resulting phenol and benzene are indicative of the initial hydrogenolysis reaction of the Caromatic-O bond. However, a subsequent increase in the reaction time provides for a higher benzene content meaning that further reaction may develop along the path of direct deoxygenation (DDO) of phenol. Cyclohexane can be obtained in two ways: either from phenol in several stages, or through benzene hydrogenation (HYD). The intermediate products of phenol conversion to cyclohexane are cyclohexanone, cyclohexanol and cyclohexene [39,48–50]. The first two products were not identified, and cyclohexene that could be a product of cyclohexanol dehydration (DHY) was found in trace quantities. This may be indicative of a partial formation of cyclohexane along the path of phenol conversion via cyclohexene. The presence of methylcyclopentane in the reaction products may indicate the occurrence of a side reaction of cyclohexane isomerization [50] or phenol hydrogenation to cyclohexanol followed by its isomerization [51]. It is worth noting that increasing the H2 pressure provides for a higher content of methylcyclopentane in the system at a higher content of cyclohexane. Therefore, it can be suggested that cyclohexane, which subsequently isomerizes, is formed mainly by the hydrogenation of benzene, and not from phenol. The presence of n-hexane may indicate not only ring opening, but also a side reaction of solvent cracking. Six runs of recycling tests were carried out to estimate the stability of NiMoS0.5◦catalyst (Fig. S1). No significant reduction in conversion was observed. However, the change in product composition indicates a decrease in the hydrogenation activity of the catalyst. At the same time, the cleavage of the Caromatic-O bond still proceeds, as evidenced by the presence of phenol and benzene as the main reaction products. In addition, increased content of benzene indicates that the deoxygenation activity of the catalyst was preserved. 4 Catalysts characterization The TEM images of the obtained catalysts show particles with a structure typical for sulfide catalysts ( Fig. 5). The MoS2 plates have the direction orthogonal to the electron beam are visualized in all images as black lines with an interlayer distance of 6.3 ± 0.1 Å were observed in TEM images. It should be noted that spherical agglomerates of sulfide particles with an average particle length of 5 nm are typical of the NiMoS2.5 catalyst. (Fig. 5(A)). No spherical agglomerates were observed after reducing the amount of the added sulfiding agent to 0.5 wt%. A significant decrease in the average particle length to 3.4 nm was noted for the NiMoS0.5 catalyst. Further decrease in the amount of the added sulfiding agent had no effect on the average particle length. The EDX-derived element maps for all NiMoS catalysts (Figs. S2–4) allow considering how the catalysts are formed in situ when changing the amount of sulfiding agent. The elements are uniformly distributed over the whole area. A dispersion of the active phase particles was calculated (Eq. (5)) on the basis of the results obtained ( Table 1). With less addition of sulfur, a more dispersed catalyst is formed. The dispersion of zeolite-supported NiMoS catalysts is known to be varying between 0.1 [52] and 0.26 [53] during hydrodeoxygenation of the fragments simulating lignin structures. Among unsupported analogs of the NiMoS catalysts obtained from both water-soluble [54] and oil-soluble [55] precursors, the dispersion of the obtained catalysts varies between 0.1 and 0.16 [56]. In our study, the dispersion of the in situ prepared unsupported NiMoS catalysts reaches 0.34 meaning that an ultrafine unsupported NiMoS catalyst that exhibits high activity in the diphenyl ether hydrodeoxygenation reaction was obtained. To determine the sulfidation degree and share of the formed phases, the in situ obtained NiMoS catalysts were analyzed using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The elemental composition of the surface of the in situ prepared NiMoS catalysts was also determined ( Table 2). Presence of oxygen on the surface of the catalysts may result from partial oxidation of the sample by the atmospheric oxygen during sample preparation. The spectra were decomposed in terms of the levels Mo3d, Ni2p and S2p for the in situ obtained NiMoS0.25, NiMoS0.5, NiMoS2.5 catalysts to determine the share of the valence state of the atoms forming the active phase of the catalysts ( Fig. 6). The Mo3d XPS spectra of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 6, and the related parameters can be seen in Table 3. Molybdenum is available on the catalyst surface in three forms: MoS2, MoO3 and MoOxSy (Fig. 6(2)). The signal with a binding energy of 229.1 ± 0.1 eV corresponds to the form MoS2 [54]. The high content of the sulfide form indicates a high degree of sulfidation of all obtained catalysts. As it can be seen the relative content of MoS2 decreases from 83.5% to 63.5% with a decrease in the addition of a sulfiding agent from 2.5% to 0.25%, respectively (Table 3). The binding energy of 230 ± 0.1 eV corresponds to the molybdenum form MoOxSy [54], and 232.7 ± 0.2 eV to the form MoO3, which correlates with the data of the publications [34,57]. For all catalysts, the oxide form content is between 2.4% and 5.0%, which may indicate a minor oxidation of the catalyst surface. Furthermore, a broad peak by approximately 226.0 eV was assigned to the S2s line [54] and subtracted from the total spectrum of Mo3d (Fig. 6(2)). Deconvolution of the level Ni2p (Fig. 6(1)) showed the presence of nickel in the form Ni-Mo-S with a binding energy about 854.4 ± 0.1 eV; the content of this phase amounted to 23.2% for NiMoS0.5, and to 46.8% in the case of the NiMoS2.5 catalyst. The binding energy of 853.3 ± 0.2 eV corresponds to the form NiSx, and an energy of 856.4 ± 0.1 eV corresponds to NiO [57]. It is worth noting that in the spectra of Ni2p levels with decreasing amount of elemental sulfur addition, the content of the sulfide form decreases whereas the oxide form increases. A similar dependence was observed for the spectra of Mo3d level. The binding energies obtained from the spectral deconvolution of the level S2p (Fig. 6(3)) testify to the presence of sulfur on the catalyst surface for the forms: S2-, S2 2- and SO4 2- [57] predominantly in the sulfide form for all catalysts. Summing up, the sulfonium thiosalts rapidly decomposes under reaction conditions, followed by formation of sulfide particles. The reducing the amount of sulfiding agent has a positive effect on the dispersity of the obtained in situ catalysts. At the same time, the results of XPS show a decrease in the degree of sulfidation and the appearance of more oxide forms on the surface of catalysts. This may caused by oxidation of the catalyst during reaction with an oxygen-containing substrate. 5 Conclusions In this study, we tried to clarify the effect of adding elemental sulfur as a sulfiding agent on the activity of the obtained catalysts. Based on the obtained reaction products, it can be stated that no sulfur-containing compounds were detected even when adding sulfur in the amount of 2.5 wt%. A 5-time reduction in the amount of the added sulfiding agent from 2.5 to 0.5 wt% resulted in the improvement of catalytic properties. In particular, the amount of 0.5 wt% provides for sulfide particles with a dispersion of 0.34 that exhibit high activity during the diphenyl ether hydrodeoxygenation. Therefore, a lower amount of sulfur added as a sulfiding agent not only can prevent the potential inclusion of sulfur in the reaction products, but also improves the quality of the NiMoS catalyst systems. coredata.dc:description: The catalytic activity of unsupported NiMoS catalysts prepared in situ by thermal decomposition of the [(CH3)3S]2Ni(MoS4)2 precursor was studied in the course of diphenyl ether hydrodeoxygenation. The resulting catalysts were characterized using the transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). It was demonstrated that the diphenyl ether conversion naturally decreases with a decrease in the precursor loading. The effect of changes in the amount of the added sulfiding agent on the morphological and structural features of the formed catalysts was studied. It was found that reducing the amount of elemental sulfur from 2.5 to 0.5 wt% results in a more active sulfide NiMo catalyst, which is explained by an increase in the dispersion of the active phase particles from 0.24 to 0.34. A route of diphenyl ether hydrodeoxygenation on unsupported NiMoS catalysts was studied and suggested by varying the reaction time and hydrogen pressure in the system.
coredata.dc:title: Hydrodeoxygenation of lignin-derived diphenyl ether on in situ prepared NiMoS catalyst: The effect of sulfur addition on catalyst formation
